Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Providing Quality of Information in Robot Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops distributed control algorithms for robot sensor networks using information dynamics to unify network mobility and communication. The new framework moves beyond location-based mobility control algorithms and packet-based communication protocols to a single information-theoretic approach. The framework is developed through: (1) formulation of a new quality of service of information metric and characterization of feasible quality of service demands, (2) adaptive receding horizon control that adjusts planning horizon and sample time based on information dynamics, (3) distributed calculation and optimization of team quality of service, and (4) experimental validation using a heterogeneous indoor robot sensor network and outdoor unmanned aircraft systems.

This research enables the collection of in situ data over large spatiotemporal scales. When deployed in remote or hazardous locations the data collected with these networks leads to a direct improvement to model or understand complex environments, which can help save lives. Students will benefit from the multi-disciplinary activities involved, including embedded computing, miniature sensor devices, wireless networking, and automatic control.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed a framework for the control of robot sensor networks that integrates sensing, communication, and actuation into a single approach based on a new concept of quality of service of information. This new framework enables robust behavior in robot sensor networks through reasoning about the combined effects of sensor uncertainty and wireless networked communication on model-based active sensing. By controlling the mobility and communication of some nodes in the system, quality of service of information, in the form of performance guarantees based on information-theoretic metrics, can be achieved. The result of the work will be increased adaptability, autonomy, efficiency, functionality, reliability, safety, and usability in robot sensor networks compared to systems that do not model uncertainty in the complex sensing and wireless communication processes. This work helps ``close the loop" in robot sensor networks by understanding and then controlling the impact of physical actuation on the performance of the cyberinfrastructure.

 

Specific outcomes of the project include

 

  1. A framework for communication-aware information gathering. This framework combined notions of information theory for sensing (mutual information) with notions of information theory in communication (Shannon capacity and erasure channels).
  2. Heuristic algorithms for online use that approximate information collected over a multi-hop network. Empirical assessment showed that planning performance was still good with the heuristic method
  3. Design and analysis of distributed control algorithms. It was shown that this communication-aware problem is not sub-modular. This property is desired as it is known that certain sequential and greedy algorithms have favorable performance bounds when it holds.
  4. An experimental system consisting of two different fixed-wing unmanned aircraft, ad-hoc meshed networking between aircraft, and radio frequency detection and tracking sensors.
  5. FAA approval for all flight operations conducted for this work. The project team was one of the first research groups to be given permission to fly multiple unmanned aircraft in the same airspace. That capability was acquired for this project, and has been exploited by the PI in several other projects supported by NSF and other funding agencies.
  6. Filed experiments demonstrating and assessing the performance of the information-gathering approach.
